titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Lewis W. Hackett Papers FA043

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-06-01 00:01:18 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lewis Wendell Hackett was born in Benicia, California, on December 14, 1884. He received an A.B. degree from Harvard University in 1905 and an M.D. from Harvard Medical School in 1912. He had become interested in public health administration and was appointed Assistant in Preventive Medicine and Hygiene at the university. During the following year, he organized and taught a laboratory and field course in hygiene. In 1913, he was granted the first Dr.P.H. degree given at Harvard Medical School. He was promoted to Instructor in Preventive Medicine and Hygiene, and in this capacity he helped to organize the first school for public health officers in the United States.

In 1914, Dr. Hackett was recruited for the field staff of the newly organized International Health Board of the Rockefeller Foundation. His next 35 years were spent in 17 foreign countries investigating and combating hookworm disease and malaria and promoting public health. His first assignment was to conduct hookworm control demonstrations in Panama, British Honduras, and Guatemala. He also took charge of the Brazilian program in 1916 and expanded the work to include malaria control and the development of public health organizations.

The second major period of Dr. Hackett's employment began in 1924 when he took charge of the International Health Board project in Italy, where malaria was active in 38 of the 69 provinces. Control demonstrations were first organized in Sardinia. His use of Paris green as a larvacide was effective and was extended to other areas. He was instrumental in establishing a Central Malaria Experiment Station in Rome for the study of the anopheline mosquito. Of the six identified varieties of the maculipennis complex, two were confirmed as significant in the spread of malaria. In 1936, Dr. Hackett set up an Albanian field station for similar anopheline research. His book, "Malaria in Europe," published in 1937, summarized his studies to date. In 1939, his field laboratory work was extended to the Nile delta in Egypt. The Foundation closed its Rome office in 1940, when Italy entered the Second World War.

The remaining nine years of Dr. Hackett's service were spent as Director of the Rio de la Plata and Andean regional office in Buenos Aires, Argentina, where he administered programs in Argentina, Chile, Ecuador, Bolivia, Peru, and Uruguay. He found a generally unpromising situation, with the medical profession dominated by politics and the public health concept erroneous or non-existent. The war, lack of qualified personnel, and political instability combined to impede progress. A health center in Chile and nursing schools in Ecuador and Peru were the most solid achievements. The rise of a totalitarian government in Argentina curbed International Health Division activities there, and the Buenos Aires office was closed in September 1949.

At his retirement in December 1949, Dr. Hackett was an Associate Director of the IHD. He settled in Berkeley, where he became Visiting Professor of Public Health at the University of California and Editor-in-Chief of the "American Journal of Tropical Medicine and Hygiene." He was a member of many scientific and learned societies and served on commissions of the League of Nations and World Health Organization. Among his many honors were decorations from the governments of Italy, Chile, Bolivia, and Ecuador. His many published articles included a contribution to the "Encyclopedia Britannica" on tropical medicine, and at his death on April 28, 1962, he was working on another book, a history of the International Health Division. Much of his material was subsequently included in Greer Williams' "The Plague Killers."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Important subjects in this collection are Argentina - Instituto de Bacteriologia, Buenos Aires; Argentina - nursing school, Rosario; Argentina - political situation, especially as it affected universities; Chile - Quinta Normal Health Center; disease control - malaria, especially in the Lurin Valley, Peru; disease control - yellow fever, especially in Bolivia and Peru; Ecuador - National Institute of Hygiene, Guayaquil; epidemiology - general; epidemiology - malaria; epidemiology - yellow fever; insecticides - Paris green, DDT and others; Peru - Ica Health Center; public health - administration; public health - nursing; Russia - general commentary after two trips; and South America - life and customs, general commentary.

Principal correspondents in this collection include William Bailey, Marston Bates, Mark F. Boyd, Elizabeth W. Brackett, Henry P. Carr, Samuel T. Darling, Harry Fultz, H. M. Gillette, Hazel Hackett, John L. Hydrick, John H. Janney, Attilio Machiavello, Hugo Muench, Laura E. Richards, F. F. Russell, Wilbur A. Sawyer, D. H. Stevens, George K. Strode, Mary E. Tennant, Andrew J. Warren, Jean Martin White, and Abigail Sanborn Hackett.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The Lewis W. Hackett collection is arranged in seven series:

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The papers of Lewis W. Hackett were deposited with the Rockefeller Foundation Archives in November 1971, December 1972, and March 1976, by Robert N. Hackett.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Foundation has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them. Rockefeller Archive Center has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is divided into three subseries:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains unbound official and personal correspondence, both to and from Dr. Hackett. Most of the letters were exchanged with persons outside his family. This is not a complete file; the letters are extremely miscellaneous in nature and appear to have been kept for personal reasons and not to constitute a record. Although the series contains little official data, there is much that illustrates his talent for vivid description of the countries in which he worked and traveled. His humor and insight make these both entertaining and informative.

did.langmaterial: Includes correspondence in English and in Spanish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains carbon copies of typewritten outgoing official correspondence. These were filed in string binders labeled "Reading File," and averaged two to three hundred letters each month. Many are in Spanish. The originals may exist in other files. The subjects are 1) routine internal Foundation business of limited interest, 2) International Health Division projects, especially in public health nursing and mosquito control, 3) fellowship recommendations and arrangements, and 4) some subjects of more than routine interest: e.g., annual estimates of funds needed for new projects. Important program developments are described in greater detail in Series 2 - Diaries.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains unbound original personal correspondence, mostly from Dr. Hackett to his wife Hazel or his mother Abbie. There are some letters from Hazel to Dr. Hackett and to his mother. Letters to and from a few others, including his son Robert, will also be found in this subseries. The major topics covered are Dr. Hackett's duties and experiences during his internships at several Boston hospitals--these double as love letters during his engagement to Hazel and occur sometimes twice daily--and the unofficial details of his first assignment with the International Health Board in Panama. The letters begin to thin out in 1919, but there is interesting material about Italy scattered throughout the 1920s and an especially fascinating group of letters in July 1934, about his first trip through Russia.

did.physloc: There is a bug with the AT that is not accepting "8D" as the value for the Container 1 Indicator field. This folder is actually in Box 8D not Box 8 located at 104/14/1.

physdesc.extent: 4 letter document boxes and 1 pamphlet box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This series is made up of official and personal diaries, both typewritten and longhand. The former are fully expanded, while the latter are usually brief notes. Some periods are missing or not covered. Most thoroughly documented are Hackett's early months in Italy in 1924 and his entire stay in Argentina from 1940 through September 1949. (All of the latter is duplicated in Hackett's diaries in the Rockefeller Foundation archives.) The years before 1924 are scarcely covered. The travel diaries are particularly interesting for human interest and local color.

did.unittitle: 1 Book (Xerox Copy) - U. S., South America, Italy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Preliminary notes for manuscript.

did.unittitle: 1 Notebook - Travel in Sumatra, Siam, Malaya, Java
1 Notebook - Travel in Java, Philippine Islands
1 Book - Travel in Egypt, Italy, South America, Canada, U.S.
Notes and Manuscripts - U.S. and Travel in Europe
7 Books - "Daily Reminder" - U.S. and Miscellaneous Travel

physdesc.extent: 1 letter document box and 1 half-legal document box

did.langmaterial: Includes materials in English, Spanish, French, Italian, or Portuguese.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Of the 33 speeches collected here, 19 were given in South America between 1940 and 1949. Most of those in Spanish or Portuguese have been translated. The subjects are epidemiology, current trends in public health, and general observations of South America. One talk includes an excellent explanation of the Foundation's aims and policies. There are also four manuscript drafts of journal articles and 32 reprints of other articles, mostly on malaria. These are arranged alphabetically by title. Included are three chapters he contributed to "Malariology," by Mark F. Boyd (2v., Saunders, 1949); his "Encyclopedia Britannica" entry on tropical medicine; and three feature stories for "Brazilian American" magazine in 1922.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The speeches in this series are arranged chronologically. They are followed by manuscript drafts of journal articles and reprints of articles. The reprints are arranged alphabetically by title. The series ends with other pieces authored by Hackett.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains two address books, two appointment books for 1951-1952 containing a few diary-type notations, and a group of pocket memo books from 1951 through March 1962, with reminders, telephone numbers, quotations, etc., mostly of a personal nature. This subseries contains little of value.

arrangement.p: This subseries is arranged alphabetically by the name of the issuing body.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains menus, programs, invitations, tickets, calling cards, blank forms, souvenirs, etc. Items of more than routine interest are a miniature hatchet pin apparently acquired from Carrie Nation, leaflets dropped from Italian war planes on Albania, and a wallet containing a variety of identity cards, licenses, etc.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries is divided into 3 sections: 1) items related to Harvard, 2) professionally-related items, and 3) miscellaneous. It is arranged chronologically thereunder.

did.unittitle: Lewis W. Hackett Photographs, Negatives, and Slides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Lewis W. Hackett Photograph Collection spans the period 1885-1962. The majority of the contents in this collection are photographs taken by Dr. Hackett during his tenure with the International Health Division/Board. Also, included in this collection are pictures of the Hackett family and home, Lewis Hackett as a child, and documentation of various ailments and diseases throughout the world. Lewis W. Hackett spent much of his career in South America and Eastern Europe, as is evidenced by the volume of photographs from these regions. The collection, however, is not limited to these regions, as nearly all of the continents are represented in the extensive visual collection. The photograph collection is housed in 41 boxes and contains photographs, negatives, slides, and post cards. Dr. Hackett was an avid and competent photographer, and varied subjects from most of the countries in which Dr. Hackett worked or traveled are represented.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This subseries has been sorted geographically and foldered either by country or region.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Negative Albums in this subseries are arranged in the order that L.W. Hackett intended. Each album is complete with a list identifying the negatives contained therein. These negative albums have corresponding prints that have been extracted and foldered. The albums and folders are housed together for cross-referencing. There appears to have been an original series of 1-13, but the existing series begins with number 4 and is missing number 9. Album 6 is missing, but the negatives remain in order and the identification list is contained in the folder. This subseries also includes a negative album that is not part of the numbered series described above. It is housed separately in box 29 and contains identification of all photos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This subseries contains 885 slides ordered alphabetically by location and chronologically within location.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Brittle or damaged items, or materials otherwise in need of preservation care, may be closed to researchers at the discretion of the RAC Head of Archival Services / Head of Reference.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This subseries contains one box of postcards arranged alphabetically by location. Many postcards have correspondence on the back.

did.unittitle: Sketch Map of India, Burma, and Ceylon. Lithograph.
Lithograph of Ceylon indicating railways and roads.
"Map of United Provinces." Indicates Malaria distribution in India (color).
